Lotto: Secure Participant Selection against Adversarial Servers
in Federated Learning

Zhifeng Jiang11{}^{\text{1}} â€‚Peng Ye11{}^{\text{1}} â€‚Shiqi He2,âˆ—2{}^{\text{2},*} â€‚Wei Wang11{}^{\text{1}} â€‚Ruichuan Chen33{}^{\text{3}} â€‚Bo Li11{}^{\text{1}}
11{}^{\text{1}}Hong Kong University of Science and Technology â€‚22{}^{\text{2}} University of Michigan â€‚33{}^{\text{3}} Nokia Bell Labs
Abstract

In Federated Learning (FL), common privacy-preserving technologies, such as secure aggregation and distributed differential privacy, rely on the critical assumption of an honest majority among participants to withstand various attacks. In practice, however, servers are not always trusted, and an adversarial server can strategically select compromised clients to create a dishonest majority, thereby undermining the systemâ€™s security guarantees. In this paper, we present Lotto, an FL system that addresses this fundamental, yet underexplored issue by providing secure participant selection against an adversarial server. Lotto supports two selection algorithms: random and informed. To ensure random selection without a trusted server, Lotto enables each client to autonomously determine their participation using verifiable randomness. For informed selection, which is more vulnerable to manipulation, Lotto approximates the algorithm by employing random selection within a refined client pool. Our theoretical analysis shows that Lotto effectively restricts the number of server-selected compromised clients, thus ensuring an honest majority among participants. Large-scale experiments further reveal that Lotto achieves time-to-accuracy performance comparable to that of insecure selection methods, indicating a low computational overhead for secure selection.

1 Introduction

Edge devices, such as smartphones and laptops, are becoming increasingly powerful and can now collaboratively build high-quality machine learning (ML) models using device-collected dataÂ [42]. To protect data privacy, large companies like Google and Apple have adopted federated learning (FL)Â [50] for tasks in computer vision (CV) and natural language processing (NLP) across client devicesÂ [38, 62, 76]. In FL, a server dynamically samples a small subset of clients from a large population in each training round. The sampled clients, aka participants, compute individual local updates using their own data and upload only the updates to the server for global aggregation, without revealing the training dataÂ [15].

However, simply keeping clientâ€™s data undisclosed is not sufficient to preserve data privacy. Recent studies have demonstrated that sensitive data can be leaked through individual updates during FL trainingÂ [35, 80, 73, 82], and it is also possible to infer a clientâ€™s data from trained modelsÂ [58, 20, 63, 52] by exploiting their ability to memorize informationÂ [20, 63]. To minimize data leakage, current FL systems employ secure aggregation techniquesÂ [16, 15, 9] to ensure that adversaries only learn the aggregate updates, not individual ones. Additionally, these systems may use distributed differential privacy (DP)Â [41, 6, 64] to limit the extent of data leakage from the aggregate update (sectionÂ 2.2). Since the server may not always be trusted, these privacy-preserving approaches commonly assume that the majority of the participants act honestly and can jointly detect and prevent server misbehavior.

Nonetheless, this assumption may not hold in practice, as an adversarial server can strategically select compromised clients that collude with it. Note that this is a feasible attack. While the entire client population is large, the target number of participants in each round is often limited to a few hundred for efficiency purposesÂ [15]. Consequently, even if the majority of the population is honest (e.g., 99% out of 100,000 clients), the server can still select a sufficient number of adversaries to create a dishonest majority among participants.

The presence of a large number of compromised participants undermines the aforementioned privacy-preserving approaches, resulting in significant vulnerabilities. As shown in sectionÂ 2.3, the privacy guarantees provided by distributed DP degrade rapidly as the dishonest cohort expandsÂ [41, 6, 64]. Furthermore, secure aggregation can only tolerate a certain proportion of clients colluding with the server; exceeding this limit would allow the adversary to reconstruct a clientâ€™s updateÂ [16]. It is hence crucial to minimize the proportion of participants that the server can manipulate during the client selection process.

Despite its importance, this problem remains largely unaddressed in the literature. The main challenge lies in the use of a central server in the cross-device FL scenariosÂ [42]. In the absence of efficient peer-to-peer communication across a vast array of heterogeneous devicesÂ [77, 44], the server serves as a central hub facilitating message exchanges between clients. Since the server is untrusted, an honest client may not have a ground truth view of other clients, such as their availability, utility, and integrity. Consequently, it is difficult for a client to audit whether the server has correctly executed the prescribed participant selection algorithm, as doing so requires ground truth knowledge of and/or inputs from other clients.

In this paper, we present Lotto, a novel system that enables secure participant selection in FL for the first time. Our key insight is that while an honest majority may not exist among participants produced by the server, it should hold among the entire client population, given the prohibitive cost of creating and operating a large number of adversarial clientsÂ [50, 9, 57]. Therefore, by incorporating verifiable randomness to the selection process, we can prevent the adversarial server from selecting an arbitrary number of dishonest participants.

Specifically, to achieve secure random selectionÂ [50], Lotto allows each client in the population to determine its participation in a training round by computing verifiable random functions (VRFs)Â [29, 51] using its secret key and public inputs. Once a client decides to participate, Lotto collects the referred randomness, along with the associated VRF proof, for other participants to verify the generation of the randomness. This approach ensures that each clientâ€™s participation is provably independent of, fair to, and unpredictable for other clients. Yet, an adversarial server may still exploit this process to grow the dishonest cohort, for example, by sending incorrect and/or a selected subset of messages. Lotto further mitigates such misconduct by enabling honest clients to verify critical messages. Lotto provides a provable guarantee that the compromised fraction of selected participants remains minimum, thereby maintaining the security guarantees offered by secure aggregation and distributed DP (sectionÂ 3.4).

Lotto is also capable of securing more advanced algorithms, referred to as informed selection, which are widely used in FL to judiciously select the best-performing participants for optimal training efficiencyÂ [81, 53, 70, 21, 45, 43]. Given that these algorithms rely on client-specific measurements (e.g., processing speed and data quality) that are difficult to verify, Lotto does not attempt to precisely follow their selection logic. Instead, it approximates them by reducing an informed selection problem to a random one. To do so, it first allows the server to refine the client pool by excluding a small fraction of low-quality clients based on the specified measurements. Lotto then performs secure random selection from the refined pool. Although an adversarial server may still attempt to manipulate this process by excluding honest clients, the security of our random selection ensures that any advantage it gains is provably small (sectionÂ 3.5).

We have implemented Lotto as a library (sectionÂ 4) and evaluated its performance with various FL tasks in a large EC2 cluster configured to emulate a cross-device scenario (sectionÂ 5).222Lotto is available at https://github.com/SamuelGong/Lotto. Compared to insecure selection algorithms, Lotto slightly increases the duration of each training round by less than 10% while achieving comparable or even better time-to-accuracy performance.

2 Background and Motivation

In this section, we begin by providing an overview of the standard FL workflow (sectionÂ 2.1). We then discuss the privacy concerns and prevalent privacy-preserving approaches that critically rely on an honest majority among participants (sectionÂ 2.2). Following this, we highlight the privacy vulnerabilities that arise when encountering a dishonest majority (sectionÂ 2.3) and ultimately present the motivation for our work.

2.1 Federated Learning

Federated learning (FL)Â [50, 42] emerges as a new private computing paradigm that enables a large number of clients to collaboratively train a global model under the orchestration of a server. The standard FL workflow is an iterative process that comprises three steps in each training roundÂ [15]. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{1}âƒ Participant Selection: the server samples a subset of eligible clients from the entire population as participants, where the eligibility criteria may include factors such as charging status and device being connected to an unmetered network. \raisebox{-1.0pt} {2}âƒ Local Training: the server distributes the global model to each participant, who then trains the model using its private data to compute a local update. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{3}âƒ Model Aggregation: the server collects local updates from participants and computes an aggregate update. This step is often coupled with additional privacy enhancement techniques (sectionÂ 2.2). The server then uses the aggregate update to refine the global model. As participants only expose their local updates instead of raw data to other parties, FL adheres to the data minimization principleÂ [42, 27] mandated by many privacy regulationsÂ [69]. Consequently, FL has been deployed to facilitate a broad range of edge intelligence applicationsÂ [38, 62, 76].

2.2 Enhancing Data Privacy in FL

Despite the fact that client data is not directly revealed during the FL training process, extensive research has demonstrated that it is still possible to disclose sensitive data through data reconstruction or membership inference attacks using individual updates or trained models. For example, an adversary can accurately reconstruct a clientâ€™s training data from its local updatesÂ [35, 80, 73, 82]; it can also infer from a trained language model whether a clientâ€™s private text has been used in the training setÂ [58, 20, 63, 52]. To effectively control the exposure of clientsâ€™ data against these attacks, FL systems commonly employ two privacy enhancement techniques: secure aggregation and distributed differential privacy.

Secure Aggregation (SecAgg)Â [16].Â Â  SecAgg is a secure multi-party computation (SMPC) protocol that enables the server to learn only the sum of clientsâ€™ updates and nothing beyond that. 2.3 Privacy Loopholes in Common Defenses

Strong Assumption on Honest Majority.Â Â  The above approaches commonly assume that the majority of participants are honest, relying on them to detect or prevent the serverâ€™s misbehavior. However, this assumption often proves inaccurate due to the necessity of participant selection in FL systems. While the overall population may be extensive, FL usually involves a limited number of sampled clients at each training round, typically in the range of a few hundredÂ [15, 42]. This limitation arises because including additional clients beyond a certain threshold only yields marginal improvements in terms of convergence accelerationÂ [50, 72]. Therefore, even if the majority (e.g., 99%) of the population (e.g., 105superscript10510^{5}) consists of honest clients, there are still a sufficient number of dishonest clients (e.g., 103superscript10310^{3}) that the server can freely select, thereby forming a dishonest majority among the participating clients. Without an honest majority across participants, the above approaches encounter significant security vulnerabilities.

Case #1: SecAgg.Â Â  SecAgg safeguards a participant iğ‘–iâ€™s plaintext update ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–\bm{x}_{i} from server probing by distributing secret shares of sâ€‹ki1ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–1sk_{i}^{1} and bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i} among other participants and requiring them to disclose only the shares of either secret to the server (sectionÂ 2.2). However, this can not be achieved if a malicious server colludes with a sufficiently large fraction of clients.

Consider a scenario with sğ‘ s participants, xğ‘¥x of which collude with the server. Let tğ‘¡t denote the threshold used by the tğ‘¡t-out-of-nğ‘›n secret sharing scheme in SecAgg. As depicted in FigureÂ 1(a), when xâ‰¥2â€‹tâˆ’sğ‘¥2ğ‘¡ğ‘ x\geq 2t-s, the server can identify two separate sets of honest participants, each containing at least tâˆ’xğ‘¡ğ‘¥t-x members. In this case, by announcing participant iğ‘–iâ€™s contradictory dropout outcome to either set, the server can collect at least tâˆ’xğ‘¡ğ‘¥t-x secret shares for both sâ€‹ki1ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–1sk_{i}^{1} and bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i}. Combining them with the shares provided by the xğ‘¥x colluding clients, the server can reconstruct sâ€‹ki1ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–1sk_{i}^{1} and bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i}, simultaneously. Ultimately, SecAgg fails to protect the local update of participant iğ‘–i, as implied by EquationÂ 1.

Case #2: Distributed DP.Â Â  Distributed DP, being built upon SecAgg, inherits the aforementioned security vulnerability. When the number of dishonest participants surpasses a specific threshold (2â€‹tâˆ’n2ğ‘¡ğ‘›2t-n as mentioned earlier), a malicious server can deduce the precise local update of participant iğ‘–i, which is perturbed solely by its noise share risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} (but not rğ‘Ÿr).

Even if this threshold is not exceeded, the security of distributed DP can still be impacted by dishonest participants. If they choose not to add any noise to their local updates, the cumulative noise added to the aggregated update will fall below the required level. This results in increased data exposure, causing the system to exhaust its privacy budget more rapidly than planned. To demonstrate this issue in a practical FL scenario, we conduct an analysis on a testbed where 700 clients collaborate to train a CNN model over the FEMNIST dataset for 50 rounds. Each round involves 70 randomly selected clients, with the task of noise addition distributed equally among all participants. However, dishonest participants will abstain from adding any noise. FigureÂ 1(b) illustrates that as the fraction of dishonest participants increases (while remaining below the SecAggâ€™s threshold mentioned earlier), the privacy deficit grows explosively, regardless of the prescribed privacy budget. For example, when 40% participants are dishonest, training with a global privacy budget ÏµG=6subscriptitalic-Ïµğº6\epsilon_{G}=6 ends up consuming an ÏµGsubscriptitalic-Ïµğº\epsilon_{G} of 11.8 at the 50th round.

3 Lotto: Secure Participant Selection

Taking the first stab at the mentioned issues, we present Lotto, a framework that secures participant selection in FL. We first establish the threat model (sectionÂ 3.1), formalize the selection problem (sectionÂ 3.2), and briefly introduce the cryptographic primitives used (sectionÂ 3.3). Next, we describe how Lotto accomplishes our goal in two scenarios: random selection (sectionÂ 3.4) and informed selection (sectionÂ 3.5). We finally provide security (sectionÂ 3.6) analysis for these methods.

3.1 Threat Model

Cross-Device Scenarios with Server-Mediated Network.Â Â  Each client has a private authenticated channel established with the server, ensuring that their transmitted messages cannot be eavesdropped on by external parties. We do not assume a peer-to-peer network among clients due to concerns regarding efficiency and scalability. Instead, clients rely on the server to mediate communication between them.

Public Key Infrastructure (PKI).Â Â  We assume a PKI that facilitates the registration of client identities and the generation of cryptographic keys on their behalf. During the setup phase, each client iğ‘–i registers its public key, denoted as (i,pkirâ€‹eâ€‹g(i,pk_{i}^{reg}), to a public bulletin board maintained by the PKI. The bulletin board only accepts registrations from clients themselves, preventing malicious parties from impersonating honest clients. Additionally, the PKI is responsible for generating the required public/secret key pair for client iğ‘–i to use in Lotto, (pâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹o,sâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹o)ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œ(pk_{i}^{Lotto{}},sk_{i}^{Lotto{}}). The PKI encrypts the secret key sâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹oğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œsk_{i}^{Lotto{}} using pâ€‹kirâ€‹eâ€‹gğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘”pk_{i}^{reg} to securely transmit them to client iğ‘–i. Meanwhile, the public key pâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹oğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œpk_{i}^{Lotto{}} is registered on the public bulletin board. The communication with the PKI is not mediated by the server.

Malicious Server with Dishonest Minority in Population.Â Â  We assume a malicious server colluding with a subset of clients in the population and they can arbitrarily deviate from the protocol. They may send incorrect or chosen messages to honest clients, abort or omit messages, or engage in Sybil attacksÂ [30] to increase the portion of clients under their control. However, we assume that the majority of the population is honest, as simulating or compromising a large number of clients incurs prohibitive costs for the adversary. The costs involved in registering numerous identities with a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) operated by a qualified trust service providerÂ [16, 9], or operating a client botnet at scale would be excessively highÂ [57]. We do not assume an honest majority across participants, as the selection outcome depends entirely on the adversary if the protocol is insecure (sectionÂ 2.3).

3.2 The Participant Selection Problem

In the FL literature, participant selection is commonly approached in two forms, both of which we aim to safeguard.

Random Selection.Â Â  The Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithmÂ [50], considered the canonical form of FL, adapts local SGDÂ [65, 37] on a randomly selected subset of clients during each round. To achieve random selection, the server can perform subsampling without replacement, where a subset of the population is chosen uniformly at random. Alternatively, it can conduct Bernoulli sampling, where each client is independently included with the same probability. We focus on the former as it guarantees a fixed sample size.

Informed Selection.Â Â  Given the large heterogeneity in device speed and/or data characteristics, several FL advancements go beyond random sampling by employing informed selection algorithmsÂ [81, 53, 70, 21, 45, 43]. These algorithms leverage client-specific measurements to identify and prioritize clients who have the greatest potential to rapidly improve the global model. Among these measurements, some can be directly monitored by the server, e.g., response latencies, while the others rely on clientsâ€™ self-reporting, e.g., training losses.

For example, Oort, the state-of-the-art informed algorithm, ranks each client iğ‘–i with a utility score UiOâ€‹oâ€‹râ€‹tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘‚ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘¡U_{i}^{Oort} that jointly considers the clientâ€™s system speed and data quality:

UiOâ€‹oâ€‹râ€‹t=|Bi|â€‹1|Bi|â€‹âˆ‘kâˆˆBiLâ€‹oâ€‹sâ€‹sâ€‹(k)2âŸDataâ€‹qualityÃ—(Tti)ğŸ™â€‹(T<ti)Ã—Î±âŸSystemâ€‹speed.subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘‚ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptâŸsubscriptğµğ‘–1subscriptğµğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğµğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘ superscriptğ‘˜2DataqualitysubscriptâŸsuperscriptğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ›¼SystemspeedU^{Oort}_{i}=\underbrace{|B_{i}|\sqrt{\frac{1}{|B_{i}|}\sum_{k\in B_{i}}Loss(k)^{2}}}_{\mathrm{Data\ quality}}\times\underbrace{(\frac{T}{t_{i}})^{\mathds{1}(T<t_{i})\times\alpha}}_{\mathrm{System\ speed}}. (3)

The first component is the aggregate training loss that reflects the volume and distribution of the clientâ€™s dataset Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}. The second component compares the clientâ€™s completion time tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i} with the developer-specified duration Tğ‘‡T and penalizes any delay (which makes the indicator ğŸ™â€‹(T<ti)1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–\mathds{1}(T<t_{i}) outputs 1) with an exponent Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0. Oort prioritizes the use of clients with high utility scores for enhanced training efficiency.

Design Goal.Â Â  Let nğ‘›n represent the population size, with cğ‘c being the number of dishonest clients, and sğ‘ s the target number of participants in a training round. Our goal, regardless of the selection approach, is to minimize the number of dishonest participants, denoted by xğ‘¥x. Ideally, xğ‘¥x should resemble c/nâ‹…sâ‹…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ c/n\cdot s, where c/nğ‘ğ‘›c/n is the base rate of dishonest clients in the population (which is presumably small, e.g., 1%, as assumed inÂ sectionÂ 3.1). However, for practical purposes, we allow for a slight relaxation of this ideal goal. We aim to align xğ‘¥x with Î·â€‹sğœ‚ğ‘ \eta s, where Î·âˆˆ(0,1)ğœ‚01\eta\in(0,1) is small enough to ensure the security of the privacy-preserving protocol implemented in the remaining FL steps.

3.3 Cryptographic Primitives

We first provide a quick primer on the cryptographic primitives involved in Lottoâ€™s solution to achieve our objective.

Verifiable Random Function (VRF)Â [51, 29].Â Â  A VRF is a public-key PRF that provides proof that its outputs were computed correctly. It consists of the following algorithms:

A secure VRF should have unique provability and pseudorandomness. The former requires that for every public key pâ€‹kğ‘ğ‘˜pk and input xğ‘¥x, there is a unique output Î²ğ›½\beta for which a proof Ï€ğœ‹\pi exists such that the verification function outputs 1. The latter requires that no adversary can distinguish a VRF output without the accompanying proof from a random string.

Signature Scheme.Â Â  A signature scheme allows a message recipient to verify that the message came from a sender it knows. It consists of the following algorithms:

  • â€¢

    (pâ€‹k,sâ€‹k)â†$currency-dollarâ†ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘ ğ‘˜absent(pk,sk)\xleftarrow{\$} SIG.gen(1Îº).superscript1ğœ…(1^{\kappa}). The key generation algorithm randomly samples a public/secret key pair (pâ€‹k,sâ€‹k)ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘ ğ‘˜(pk,sk) from the security parameter Îºğœ…\kappa.

    Ïƒâ†â†ğœabsent\sigma\leftarrowSIG.sign(m)sâ€‹k{}_{sk}(m). The sign function receives a binary string mğ‘šm and a secret key sâ€‹kğ‘ ğ‘˜sk and generates a signature Ïƒğœ\sigma.

  • â€¢

    {0,1}â†â†01absent\{0,1\}\leftarrowSIG.ver(pâ€‹k,m,Ïƒ)ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘šğœ(pk,m,\sigma). The verification function receives a public key pâ€‹kğ‘ğ‘˜pk and two strings mğ‘šm and Ïƒğœ\sigma, and outputs either 0 or 1.

For correctness, a signature scheme must ensure that the verification algorithm outputs 1 when presented with a correctly generated signature for any given message. For security, we require that no PPT adversary, when given a fresh honestly generated public key and access to a signature oracle, can produce a valid signature on a message on which the oracle was queried with non-negligible probability.

Pseudorandom Function (PRF)Â [36].Â Â  A secure PRF(x)k{}_{k}(x) is a family of deterministic functions indexed by a key kğ‘˜k that map an input xğ‘¥x into an output in such a way that the indexed function is computationally indistinguishable from the output of a truly random function with input xğ‘¥x.

3.4 Secure Random Selection

A faithful execution of random selection naturally achieves our goal (sectionÂ 3.2). However, enforcing this in the presence of a malicious server poses two key challenges:

  • â€¢

    Correctness (C1): A malicious server can deviate from random selection while falsely claiming adherence to the protocol. How can clients prevent such misbehavior?

  • â€¢

    Consistency (C2): Even if the protocol is faithfully executed, how can we ensure that the participants in the subsequent workflow are indeed those who were selected?

Self-Sampling with Verifiable Randomness.Â Â  To address C1, we propose a self-sampling approach where each individual client in the population is responsible for determining whether it should participate in a training round based on publicly available inputs. The key intuition is that honest clients, which form the majority of the population, have a strong incentive to follow a reasonable selection plan due to concerns about preserving their own privacy. For security, we need to tackle the following adversarial issues simultaneously:

  • â€¢

    T1.1: Ensuring that dishonest clients cannot participate without following the prescribed self-sampling protocol.

  • â€¢

    T1.2: Ensuring that honest clients who choose to participate do not get arbitrarily omitted by the dishonest server.

To accomplish T1.1, Lotto introduce verifiable randomness to the self-sampling process to allow each participant to verify the integrity of other peersâ€™ execution. Specifically, we utilize a VRF with range [0,m)0ğ‘š[0,m), and assume that the FL training needs to randomly sample sğ‘ s out of nğ‘›n clients for a specific training round rğ‘Ÿr. At the beginning of the round, the server first announces sğ‘ s, nğ‘›n, rğ‘Ÿr to all clients in the population. Each client iğ‘–i then generates a random number Î²isubscriptğ›½ğ‘–\beta_{i} and the associated proof Ï€isubscriptğœ‹ğ‘–\pi_{i} using its private key sâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹oğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œsk_{i}^{Lotto{}} via Î²i,Ï€i=subscriptğ›½ğ‘–subscriptğœ‹ğ‘–absent\beta_{i},\pi_{i}= VRF(r)sâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹o{}_{sk_{i}^{Lotto{}}}(r). To achieve an expectation of sğ‘ s sampled clients, only those clients with Î²i<sâ€‹m/nsubscriptğ›½ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘›\beta_{i}<sm/n will claim to participate by uploading their Î²isubscriptğ›½ğ‘–\beta_{i}â€™s and Ï€isubscriptğœ‹ğ‘–\pi_{i}â€™s to the server, while the remaining clients abort. Next, the server takes all the surviving clients Pğ‘ƒP as participants and dispatches the collected {Î²i,Ï€i}iâˆˆPsubscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘–subscriptğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘ƒ\{\beta_{i},\pi_{i}\}_{i\in P} to each of them. Finally, each participant iğ‘–i verifies the validity and eligibility of its peersâ€™ randomness, i.e., checking if VRF.valâ€‹(pâ€‹kjLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹o,r,Î²j,Ï€j)=1VRF.valğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ›½ğ‘—subscriptğœ‹ğ‘—1\textrm{{VRF.val}}(pk_{j}^{Lotto{}},r,\beta_{j},\pi_{j})=1 and Î²j<sâ€‹m/nsubscriptğ›½ğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘›\beta_{j}<sm/n for each jâˆˆPğ‘—ğ‘ƒj\in P. By security of VRFs (sectionÂ 3.3), if all the sâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹oğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œsk_{i}^{Lotto{}}â€™s are uniformly random (guaranteed by the PKI as implied inÂ sectionÂ 3.1), this process is pseudorandom where each client is selected equally likely with probability s/nğ‘ ğ‘›s/n. Also, the participation of a dishonest client iğ‘–i will not be acknowledged by honest clients, if its associated randomness falls outside the publicly known range [0,sâ€‹m/n)0ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘›[0,sm/n) or fails to pass the VRF verification test parameterized by the public key pâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹oğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œpk_{i}^{Lotto{}} issued by the PKI.

Over-Selection with Indiscriminate Removal.Â Â  While VRFs securely achieve Bernoulli sampling, our primarily desired form of random selection is subsampling without replacement (sectionÂ 3.2). To achieve a fixed sample size, Lotto further employs over-selection with indiscriminate removal based on the above process. Specifically, instead of directly targeting sğ‘ s sampled clients, Lotto slightly increases the expected sample size by a factor Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1. In this case, clients identify themselves as candidate participants Cğ¶C when their associated Î²isubscriptğ›½ğ‘–\beta_{i}â€™s satisfy Î²i<Î±â€‹sâ€‹m/nsubscriptğ›½ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘›\beta_{i}<\alpha sm/n. Next, the server fairly samples sğ‘ s candidates out of Cğ¶C uniformly at random to finalize the set of participants Pğ‘ƒP, if the total number of candidates is no less than the required sample size sğ‘ s. Otherwise, Lotto aborts the current round. As we observed in practice (FigureÂ 2), a small value of Î±ğ›¼\alpha around 1.3 suffices to sample enough clients with high probability. A more rigorous analysis is provided in AppendixÂ A.

Constraints on Population Size against Malicious Coordination.Â Â  Although the use of VRFs prevents the server from freely selecting a dishonest client to participate, it is still possible for it to exploit the process and increase the ratio of dishonest participants. This can be done during the finalization of participants, where the server can remove honest candidates, not just the ones with randomly chosen indices. To prevent such misconduct (T1.2), a simple fix is to enforce execution integrity using trusted execution environments (TEEs)Â [26]. However, the feasibility of TEEs depends not only on the serverâ€™s hardware support but also on clientsâ€™ trust in the hardware manufacturers. Also, TEE security is not infallible, as it remains susceptible to side-channel attacksÂ [22, 68].

Fortunately, while enforcing execution integrity could be complex, the serverâ€™s ability to grow the ratio of dishonest participants can still be controlled indirectly by reasonable use of parameters in Lotto. To ensure that dishonest clients remain a minority among the participants, regardless of how the server removes honest candidates, it is sufficient to guarantee that the number of dishonest candidates xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime} is significantly smaller than the target number of participants sğ‘ s. This way, even if the server deliberately includes all dishonest candidates in the final participants, as long as the number of participants is required to be fixed at sğ‘ s, the remaining participants, which constitute the majority, have to be honest clients. To establish an upper bound for ğ”¼â€‹[xâ€²]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘¥â€²\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}], we require a sufficiently large population size nğ‘›n, because ğ”¼â€‹[xâ€²]=câ‹…Î±â€‹s/nğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘¥â€²â‹…ğ‘ğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘›\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}]=c\cdot\alpha s/n and all parameters cannot be manipulated by the server except for nğ‘›n. Thus, Lotto let honest clients agree upon a minimum acceptable population size, denoted as nminsubscriptğ‘›minn_{\text{min}}, and abort if the announced nğ‘›n falls below this threshold.

Inter-Client Consistency via Signature Scheme.Â Â  While we have ensured that each participant iğ‘–i333We do not consider the views of non-participant clients in a round, as they are not of concern regarding data privacy. receives a selection outcome where each member appears with probability lower-bounded, the issue of guaranteeing identical outcomes among all participants remains. To address this concern, Lotto employs a secure signature scheme, which operates as follows:

  • â€¢

    Each client signs its received selection outcome Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} with its registration secret key sâ€‹kirâ€‹eâ€‹gğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘”sk_{i}^{reg}, generating a signature Ïƒi=subscriptğœğ‘–absent\sigma_{i}= SIG.sign(r||Pi)sâ€‹kirâ€‹eâ€‹g{}_{sk_{i}^{reg}}(r||P_{i}) where |||| denotes concatenation.

  • â€¢

    After collecting all signatures from a set of clients Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}, the server broadcasts to them the set {(j,Ïƒj)}jâˆˆPâ€²subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘—superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\{(j,\sigma_{j})\}_{j\in P^{\prime}} containing the received signatures.

  • â€¢

If any failure occurs during verification, the client aborts.

In summary, by addressing C1 with the above design, honest participants are ensured to proceed only with a consistent participant list with each member randomly presenting with probability less than Î±â€‹s/nmâ€‹iâ€‹nğ›¼ğ‘ subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›\alpha s/n_{min}. This upper bound remains invariant during the training, as it is fully determined by public values. Hence, it can be used to derive practical security guarantees (sectionÂ 3.6), regardless of misbehaviors exhibited by the server, e.g., claiming an inaccurate nğ‘›n.

Inherent Inter-Stage Consistency with SecAgg.Â Â  Ensuring consistency in participant sets used by the server throughout the entire FL workflow (C2) poses inherent difficulties. On one hand, if the privacy-preserving protocol used in the later stage mandates that all participants observe a genuine selection outcome to ensure valid computation, C2 is inherently addressed without additional measures. However, if the server can secretly involve a participant set different from the announced one while still observing meaningful exchanged messages, the attainability of C2 becomes an open question, as honest participants cannot detect such deception with limited trusted source of information (sectionÂ 3.1).

Fortunately, the protocol commonly employed in the remaining workflow is SecAgg (or the distributed differential privacy built upon it) (sectionÂ 2.2), where the server has an incentive to uphold the actual selection outcome during the entire training. First, it gains no advantage by secretly involving additional dishonest clients. In SecAgg integrated with Lotto, an honest participant iğ‘–i establishes secure channels with peers solely by using the public keys pâ€‹kjrâ€‹eâ€‹gğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘”pk_{j}^{reg} contained in the selection outcome Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} finalized by Lotto. Therefore, it will not share any additional secrets with clients outside of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}, even if they participate in the halfway. Second, the server will not pretend arbitrarily many dropout events of selected honest participants, e.g., by omitting their messages. This is because SecAgg enforces a minimum number of participants (i.e., tğ‘¡t) remaining in the final stage, beyond which the aggregation will abort without providing any meaningful information.

Full Protocol: Client-Centric v.s. Server-Centric.Â Â  Putting it all together, the above design of Lotto can be summarized by FigureÂ 3. We refer to this algorithm as Client-Centric since the selection step primarily occurs at the client end. Client-Centric effectively achieves the security goal outlined inÂ sectionÂ 3.2. We provide a detailed analysis of its security inÂ sectionÂ 3.6 and assess its complexity inÂ appendixÂ B.

It is worth noting that there exists an alternative design that may initially appear to be a natural choice. This design retains the core elements of Client-Centric but relies on the server to perform the random selection. Specifically, for each client iğ‘–i in the population, the server uses a PRF with range [0,m)0ğ‘š[0,m) to generate a random value Î²i=PRFpâ€‹kiLâ€‹oâ€‹tâ€‹tâ€‹oâ€‹(r)subscriptğ›½ğ‘–subscriptPRFğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘Ÿ\beta_{i}=\textrm{{PRF}}_{pk_{i}^{Lotto{}}}(r), and selects it as a participant if Î²i<Î±â€‹sâ€‹m/nsubscriptğ›½ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘›\beta_{i}<\alpha sm/n. The selection outcome, along with the associated randomness, is communicated to each participant for verification purposes. We refer to this design as Server-Centric. Intuitively, Server-Centric offers the same security guarantee as Client-Centric does in a single training round, as it also provides honest clients with a consistent participant list with members presenting equally likely within a preset probability upper bound.

However, Server-Centric faces an additional security challenge during multiple-round training. As the selection outcome relies solely on public inputs, a malicious server can accurately predict, before online training, whether an honest participant iğ‘–i will be selected in a specific round rğ‘Ÿr. This predictability opens up opportunities for the adversary to exploit the system. For instance, during the participant finalization stage in each round, the server in Server-Centric can deliberately ensure that the most frequently appearing candidate is not removed. In the context of DP training, this deterministic coordination behavior implies a weaker level of privacy guarantee. We give a rigorous security comparison in AppendixÂ D. Considering the similarity of the empirical runtime overhead between the two designs (sectionÂ 5.2), we adopt Client-Centric as Lotto primary design for its stronger security.

3.5 Secure Informed Selection

Challenges.Â Â  Unlike random selection, informed selection does not inherently incorporate randomness, but heavily relies on client measurements (sectionÂ 3.2). This presents two challenges in our pursuit of controlling the number of dishonest participants. Consider OortÂ [45] as an example, where a clientâ€™s response latency and training loss are employed as proxies for system speed and data quality, respectively (sectionÂ 3.2). First, the adversary can manipulate these metrics for selecting more colluding clients. Lacking a ground truth view on these metrics, detecting such deception is hard for honest clients. Second, even if adversaries refrain from actively corrupting any measurements, they can still involve more dishonest clients by genuinely improving their system speed or data quality. Such exploitation is more covert to detect.

Approximation with Introduced Randomness.Â Â  To side-step the above issues, Lotto introduces randomness to the selection process by incorporating secure random selection (sectionÂ 3.4) to approximate a given informed algorithm. The server first refines the population by excluding a fraction dğ‘‘d of clients with the lowest utility, based on the original criteria employed in the algorithm. It then applies secure random selection to the refined population. For example, if the original algorithm prioritizes the fastest clients, Lotto approximates it by first excluding the slowest dğ‘‘d of clients before random selection.

Note that Lotto does not enforce the integrity of the refinement process due to the aforementioned challenges, and thus the server has the flexibility to purposely exclude honest clients, not just the â€œbadâ€ clients. However, we can tolerate such adversarial scenarios to some extent by ensuring that dğ‘‘d is small. For instance, as illustrated in FigureÂ 4, if the server is allowed to exclude 20% of the population, the maximum increase in the base rate of dishonest clients in the refined population would be less than 25%. In Lotto, the regulation of dğ‘‘d can be achieved by appropriately setting nmâ€‹iâ€‹nsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›n_{min}, i.e., the minimum accepted size of the remaining population (sectionÂ 3.4).

Population refinement can be considered as a preprocessing step taken before secure random selection (FigureÂ 3). Hence, Lottoâ€™s approach to informed selection inherits all the security properties of its random selection, as discussed inÂ sectionÂ 3.6.

Effectiveness of Population Refinement.Â Â  Consider the following single-metric scenario without loss of generality: the original algorithm selects the best sğ‘ s clients out of the initial population of size niâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡n_{init} based on a metric Xğ‘‹X (Case A). When employing Lotto, sğ‘ s clients are randomly selected from the refined population of size n=niâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹(1âˆ’d)ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡1ğ‘‘n=n_{init}(1-d) (Case B).

The extent to which Lotto approximates the original algorithm relies on the disparity in participant quality, as measured by Xğ‘‹X, between Case A and Case B. This difference, in turn, depends on the distribution of Xğ‘‹X across the initial population. Intuitively, Lotto best approximates the original algorithm when Xğ‘‹X follows a long-tailed distribution (e.g., power-law distributionsÂ [25]), where the majority of the population is considered â€œgood" and only a small fraction is deemed â€œbadâ€. In this case, Lotto can exclude almost all the relatively few "bad" participants. For example, suppose that Xğ‘‹X is the smaller, the better, and it follows Zipfâ€™s distribution parameterized by pğ‘p, such that the Xğ‘‹X value of the iğ‘–i-th worst client is proportional to iâˆ’psuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘i^{-p}. In this case, precluding the worst dğ‘‘d of the initial population enhances the quality of the worst client that can be selected by (1âˆ’d)âˆ’psuperscript1ğ‘‘ğ‘(1-d)^{-p}, as shown in FigureÂ 5.

At the other extreme, there could be a scenario where the majority of clients are classified as "bad" while only a minority of them are deemed "good." In this case, our approximation may not yield participants of sufficiently high quality compared to the original algorithm. We acknowledge this limitation yet contend that this compromise is a necessary cost in order to secure the selection process.

Handling Multiple-Metric Algorithms.Â Â  In the cases where the original algorithm incorporates two or more independent metrics, a straightforward approach to conducting population refinement is the Or strategy which excludes the worst clients based on one of the metrics. Alternatively, we can also adopt the And strategy that excludes clients that perform poorly in all metrics simultaneously. Furthermore, if the original informed algorithm combines the information from the two metrics into a single comprehensive metric, such as what Oort defines as the utility score (sectionÂ 3.2), there further exists a Joint strategy which directly relies on this single metric for population refinement. We advocate the adoption of Or due to its superiority demonstrated in empirical experiments (sectionÂ 5.3).

3.6 Security Analysis

CorollaryÂ 1 provides insights into the robustness of Lotto in maintaining the security of SecAgg, while CorollaryÂ 2 outlines the end-to-end privacy guarantees offered by Lotto when integrated with existing distributed differential privacy (DP) systems. In contrast, insecure selection would result in a prohibitive cost of Ïµ=265italic-Ïµ265\epsilon=265 (FigureÂ 6(c)).

Secure Informed Selection.Â Â  Population refinement in our informed selection can be considered as a preprocessing step that precedes our random selection (sectionÂ 3.5). Hence, the security guarantee provided by our informed selection can be derived from that of our random selection. Assume that the initial population consists of niâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡n_{init} clients, with cğ‘c being the number of dishonest clients. Denote by nğ‘›n the size of the refined population. As the server can act maliciously by deliberately excluding honest clients, in the worst case, all cğ‘c dishonest clients remain in the refined population. Therefore, the security guarantee can be derived by directly applying TheoremÂ 1.

4 Implementation

We have implemented Lotto as a library easily pluggable into existing FL systems with 1235 lines of Python code. It operates within the server and on each client, interacting with the underlying framework of an FL execution.

System Workflow.Â Â  FigureÂ 7 shows how Lotto interacts with the FL execution frameworks during participant selection. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{1}âƒ Pool Confirmation: the framework forms a pool with clients meeting eligibility properties (e.g., battery level) and forward their identities and characteristics (e.g., latency) to Lotto. In case of informed selection, the server-end refines the pool by excluding those clients who have the worst utility, based on the original criteria applied in the original algorithm. Lotto next proceeds to random selection and has two variants. \raisebox{-0.4pt}{\footnotesize2a}âƒ Server-Centric Selection: the server-end over-selects participants from the pool as candidates using PRFs. \raisebox{-0.4pt}{\footnotesize2b}âƒ Client-Centric Selection: for each client in the pool, the server-end informs its client-end to self-sample with VRFs. Clients meeting the participation conditions report their results and become candidates. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{3}âƒ Mutual Verification: the server fairly selects the target number of clients from the candidate list as participants. It then helps each participant check its peersâ€™ qualification and their seen outcomes. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{4}âƒ Participant Finalization. The FL framework proceeds with the selection outcome output by Lotto and starts FL training.

Cryptographic Instantiation.Â Â  Secure PRFs can be implemented with a cryptographic hash function in conjunction with a secret key, and we use HMAC-SHA-256. For secure signature schemes, we utilize Ed25519Â [10], an elliptic-curve-based signature scheme. Both of the above choices are implemented leveraging the cryptography Python libraryÂ [1]. We implement VRFs using ECVRF-Ed25519-SHA512-Elligator2 as specified inÂ [3] using the codebase provided byÂ [5].

5 Evaluation

We evaluate Lottoâ€™s effectiveness in various FL training testbeds. The highlights of our evaluation are listed below.

  1. 1.

    Compared to insecure selection methods, Lotto introduces at most 10% runtime overhead and negligible extra network usage across different participation scales (sectionÂ 5.2).

  2. 2.

    In the case of informed selection, the adoption of Lotto achieves comparable or even superior training efficiency compared to that of insecure methods (sectionÂ 5.3).

5.1 Methodology

Datasets and Models.Â Â  We run two common categories of applications with three real-world datasets of different scales.

  • â€¢

    Image Classification: the FEMNISTÂ [18] dataset, with 805k images classified into 62 classes, and a more complicated dataset OpenImageÂ [2] with 1.5M images spanning 600 categories. We train a CNNÂ [41, 6], and MobileNet V2 Â [55] with 0.25 as width multiplier to classify the images in FEMNIST and OpenImage, respectively.

  • â€¢

    Language Modeling: the large-scale Reddit datasetÂ [4]. We train next-word predictions with Albert modelÂ [46].

Cluster Setup.Â Â  We launch an AWS EC2 r5n.8xlarge instance (32 vCPUs, 256 GB memory, and 25 Gbps network) for the server and one c5.xlarge (4 vCPUs and 8 GB memory) instance for each client, aiming to match the computing power of mobile devices. We also throttle clientsâ€™ bandwidth to fall at 44Mbps to match the average mobile bandwidthÂ [24].

Hyperparameters.Â Â  For local training, we use the mini-batch SGD for FEMNIST and OpenImage and AdamWÂ [48] for Reddit, all with momentum set to 0.9. The number of training rounds and local epochs are 50 and 2 for both FEMNIST and Reddit and 100 and 3 for OpenImage, respectively. The batch size is consistently 20 across three tasks, while the learning rate is fixed at 0.01 for FEMNIST and 8e-5 for Reddit, respectively. For OpenImage, the initial learning rate is 0.050.050.05, and decreases by a factor of 0.98 after every 10 rounds. For model aggregation, we apply weighted averagingÂ [50] protected by the SecAggÂ [16] protocol (sectionÂ 2.2).

Baselines.Â Â  In evaluating random selection, we compare Lotto against RandÂ [50], the naive random selection protocol. As for informed selection, we compare Lotto against OortÂ [45], the state-of-the-art informed algorithm designed for maximum training efficiency. Both Oort and Rand are considered insecure as the server has the freedom to include dishonest clients. For Lotto, we primarily evaluate the Client-Centric approach, while also demonstrating its efficiency similarity with the Server-Centric approach (sectionÂ 3.4).

5.2 Execution Efficiency

We assess the time performance and network overhead of Lotto. To study the impact of the federation scale, we vary the population size from 100 to 400 to 700. The target sampled clients are proportionately set to 10, 40, and 70, respectively.

Lotto Induces Acceptable Overhead in Time.Â Â  FigureÂ 8 summarizes the average round time in random selection, broken down into two parts: local training (â€˜trainâ€™), and the remaining workflow operations (â€˜otherâ€™). It also shows the runtime portion of the latter, helping the reader understand the characteristics of various FL tasks. When compared to Rand, Lotto implemented with Client-Centric incurs a time cost of less than 6%, 8%, and 10% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively. Moreover, the overhead for Server-Centric is 1%, 4%, and 3%, respectively. Such acceptable overhead is expected as Lotto is built on lightweight security primitives (3.4). As for informed selection, all the observed trends are identical to those reported in FigureÂ 8 (with Rand replaced by Oort). We thus defer the results to AppendixÂ E for brevity.

Lotto Induces Negligible Overhead in Network.Â Â  FigureÂ 9 illustrates the network footprint per round at the server end during random selection, categorized into two components: the outbound part (â€˜sendâ€™) and the inbound part (â€˜recvâ€™). As one can see, Lotto introduces less than 1% additional network footprint across all evaluated tasks and all participation scales. This can be attributed to the fact that the predominant communication overhead in FL is the transmission of the model, rather than other auxiliary information. For example, when training over Reddit with 700 clients, model transfer in a round yields a network footprint of approximately 6.6 GB to the server (Fig.Â 9(c)). In contrast, the extra cost brought by Client-Centric and Server-Centric are merely 1.3 MB and 0.3 MB, respectively. As for informed selection, again, we defer them to AppendixÂ E given the identical implications.

Client-Centric v.s. Server-Centric.Â Â  The preceding analysis emphasizes Lottoâ€™s minimal time and network costs, irrespective of whether it is implemented using a Client-Centric or Server-Centric approach. Since both approaches demonstrate comparable efficiency in practice, we recommend adopting the latter, as it ensures enhanced security through the unpredictability of selection outcomes, as outlined inÂ sectionÂ 3.4.

5.3 Effectiveness of Informed Selection

We next evaluate the effectiveness of Lottoâ€™s approximation strategies in achieving the objectives of the target informed selection algorithm. We focus on the Client-Centric implementation of Lotto and use the 700-client testbed (sectionÂ 5.2).

Heterogeneous Environment.Â Â  The realistic datasets we employ (sectionÂ 5.1) already demonstrate data heterogeneity, as they are partitioned by the original data owners. FigureÂ 10(a) toÂ 10(c) provides a visualization of clientsâ€™ data quality, as measured by Oortâ€™s definition (the first term in EquationÂ (3)) without loss of generality. Snapshots of clientsâ€™ status are taken across different rounds of the training. On the other hand, for the adoption of Oort to be meaningful, we need to additionally emulate hardware heterogeneity. To this end, we set the response latencies of clients to consistently follow a Zipf distribution parameterized by a=1.2ğ‘1.2a=1.2 (moderately skewed), regardless of the specific FL task, as illustrated in Figure 10(d).

The Or Strategy Outperforms Other Choices of Lotto.Â Â  Lotto considers various strategies for population refinement when approximating the target informed algorithm (sectionÂ 3.5). Here, we compare them using a consistent exclusion threshold of 20%. Under this threshold, a client is excluded if it ranks in the bottom 20% in either system speed or data quality (Or); in both metrics (And); or in the comprehensive utility score (EquationÂ (3)) defined by Oort (Joint). Additionally, we include the Rand method as a baseline reference. As illustrated inÂ 11, Or and Joint constantly outperforms Rand, while And fails to surpass it in certain cases, e.g., FEMNIST (Fig.Â 11(a)). This can be attributed to the independent distributions of system speed and data quality across clients. As there are only a few clients that rank in the bottom 20% simultaneously for both metrics (observed to be â‰¤\leq5% of the population), the number of clients that And excludes is inadequate. Between Or and Joint, we advocate the use of the former due to its consistently superior performance and fix its use for the remaining analysis.

Lotto Achieves Comparable or Even Superior Performance to Oort.Â Â  To examine the time-to-accuracy performance, we set the target accuracy at 69.8% and 27.6% for FEMNIST and OpenImage, respectively. For Reddit, we set the target perplexity (lower values are better) at 1010. As depicted in FigureÂ 11, Lotto achieves nearly identical performance to Oort in OpenImage, and it even surpasses Oort by 1.1Ã—\times for both FEMNIST and Reddit. In comparison to Rand, Lotto outperforms it by 2.1Ã—\times, 3.0Ã—\times, and 1.6Ã—\times in FEMNIST, OpenImage, and Reddit, respectively. Note that we have accounted for the disparity in execution efficiency between Lotto and baselines (sectionÂ 5.2) for fairness of comparison. These results underscore the significant enhancement in the quality of selected clients through population refinement, specifically employing the Or strategy with a 20% exclusion factor, making it competitive with Oort which cherrypicks the best clients. Overall, the randomness introduced by Lotto for ensuring security guarantees (sectionÂ 3.6) does not compromise the training efficiency achieved by insecure methods.

6 Discussion and Future Work

General Solutions for Inter-Stage Consistency.Â Â  Lotto does not explicitly ensure consistent reference to a participant list throughout the entire FL workflow. This is because, for SecAgg that this paper primarily focuses on, any inconsistent reference by the server offers no significant advantage in probing clientsâ€™ data (sectionÂ 3.4). This applies to other secure aggregation protocols, such as SecAgg+Â [9], the state-of-the-art follow-up work of SecAgg. Similar to SecAgg, SecAgg+ ensures that each participant will not share secrets with clients beyond its verified participant list, and also includes controllable dropout tolerance that can prevent the server from pretending the dropout of numerous honest participants. However, it would be beneficial to explore general solutions for achieving inter-stage consistency when combining Lotto with other potential protocols in the future.

7 Related Work

Privacy-Preserving Aggregation with Malicious Server.Â Â  Numerous protocols have been proposed to enable a server to learn the sum of multiple inputs without gaining access to individual inputs. However, many of these protocols assume an honest-but-curious serverÂ [40, 60, 61] or a trusted third partyÂ [13, 23, 32], which has limited practicality. Only the commonly used SecAggÂ [16] and SecAgg+Â [9] and a few other protocolsÂ [49, 47, 78, 54] allow for a malicious server. To further control the information leakage through the sum, distributed DP protocolsÂ [41, 6, 64, 39] provide rigorous privacy guarantees by combining the DP noise addition with SecAgg. However, both secure aggregation and distributed DP are still vulnerable to the privacy risks posed by a dishonest majority among participants, while Lotto takes the initiative to tackle this issue by secure participant selection.

Secure Federated Training against Adversaries.Â Â  Besides probing data privacy, an adversary may also compromise the global model performance during FL trainingÂ [8, 7, 12, 33, 56, 67, 71]. Several approaches have been proposed to mitigate these attacks, e.g., by employing certifiable techniques during local trainingÂ [19, 74], or applying dimension-wise filteringÂ [79, 11], vector-wise scalingÂ [66, 34], or vector-wise filteringÂ [14, 59, 75, 17] to model aggregation. These works back up Lotto with robust model performance, whereas Lotto enhances data privacy by secure participant selection.

8 Conclusion

In FL, various aggregation protocols have been developed to enhance clientsâ€™ data privacy. However, the participant selection mechanisms they rely on remain vulnerable to manipulation by adversarial servers. In this paper, we have proposed Lotto, an FL system that addresses the critical issue of secure participant selection against an adversarial server. Lotto provides two selection algorithms, random and informed, both of which effectively restrict the number of server-selected compromised clients, thereby ensuring an honest majority among participants. Theoretical analysis and large-scale experiments demonstrate that Lotto not only provides increased security but also achieves time-to-accuracy performance comparable to that of insecure selection methods.

Appendix A Over-Selection

Theorem 2 (Effectiveness of Over-Selection).

Using an over-selection factor Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0, the described process in Lotto results in at least sğ‘ s candidates with probability of 1âˆ’âˆ‘i=0âŒŠsâˆ’1âŒ‹(ni)â€‹piâ€‹(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’i1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–0ğ‘ 1binomialğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscript1ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘–1-\sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor s-1\rfloor}\binom{n}{i}p^{i}(1-p)^{n-i} where p=Î±â€‹s/nğ‘ğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘›p=\alpha s/n.

Appendix B Complexity Analysis

Let nğ‘›n be the initial population size, and sğ‘ s the target number of sampled clients. We also abuse the symbol nğ‘›n to represent the refined population size, as both should be of the same magnitude. For secure random selection, Client-Centric induces an overhead of Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) and Oâ€‹(n+s2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ‘ 2O(n+s^{2}) to the serverâ€™s computation and communication, respectively, while those incurred to a selected client are Oâ€‹(s)ğ‘‚ğ‘ O(s) and Oâ€‹(s)ğ‘‚ğ‘ O(s), respectively. In Server-Centric, the computation and communication for the server are Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) and Oâ€‹(s2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘ 2O(s^{2}), respectively, while those for a selected client are Oâ€‹(s)ğ‘‚ğ‘ O(s) and Oâ€‹(s)ğ‘‚ğ‘ O(s), respectively. For informed selection, the overhead of the serverâ€™s computation in Client-Centric becomes Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n), while other terms of overhead remain the same, compared to random selection.

Appendix D Client-Centric v.s. Server-Centric

As indicated inÂ sectionÂ 3.4, we consider the Client-Centric design as the primary approach for Lottoâ€™s random selection, because it offers superior security guarantees in the context of multiple-round training. In order to measure the disparity, we focus on multiple-round DP training, where the privacy cost is contingent upon the client selected for the maximum number of times, assuming a fixed noise multiplier. With the Client-Centric approach, the server cannot determine which client will be selected in a specific round rğ‘Ÿr until the selection process takes place. Consequently, a malicious server cannot definitively identify the very participant who will turn out to be the most frequent candidates during the finalization of participants for each round. In other words, the server can only reserve it with some probability less than 1. In contrast, with the Server-Centric approach, the server can reserve the aforementioned client with certainty due to the predictability of the selection outcomes even before the training begins. As a result, compared to Client-Centric, Server-Centric provides the adversary with less randomness, which has implications for its security guarantees. More formally, when it comes to training with distributed DP, from TheoremÂ 1 we can derive the following corollary for Server-Centric:

Corollary 3 (Controlled Privacy Cost in Distributed DP, II).

Appendix E Execution Efficiency of Informed Selection

FigureÂ 13 and FigureÂ 14 present a comparison between Lottoâ€™s informed selection and Oort in terms of average time cost and network footprint at the server end during a training round, respectively. When compared to Oort, the Lotto implementation using the Client-Centric approach incurs a time cost of less than 5%, 10%, and 5% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively. Additionally, the overhead for Server-Centric is 2%, 0%, and 0%, respectively. Regarding the network footprint, Lotto introduces less than 1% additional network footprint across all evaluated tasks and participation scales. The observed trend indicates that Lotto maintains an acceptable time cost and negligible network overhead during informed selection, similar to the findings in random selection (sectionÂ 5.2).
